column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.2
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Referent|entity|infstat
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=Andrew Amos
#Text=I took the train three days later from King 's Cross to Edinburgh .
#Text=I went to the Pentland Hotel in Princes Street and left there a suit-case containing some clean linen and a change of clothes .
#Text=I had been thinking the thing out , and had come to the conclusion that I must have a base somewhere and a fresh outfit .
#Text=Then in well-worn tweeds and with no more luggage than a small trench kit-bag , I descended upon the city of Glasgow .
#Text=I walked from the station to the address which Blenkiron had given me .
#Text=It was a hot summer evening , and the streets were filled with bareheaded women and weary-looking artisans .

#Text=As I made my way down the Dumbarton Road I was amazed at the number of able-bodied fellows about , considering that you could n't stir a mile on any British front without bumping up against a Glasgow battalion .
#Text=Then I realized that there were such things as munitions and ships , and I wondered no more .
#Text=A stout and dishevelled lady at a close-mouth directed me to Mr Amos 's dwelling . '
#Text=Twa stairs up .
#Text=Andra will be in noo , havin ' his tea .
#Text=He 's no yin for overtime .
#Text=He 's generally hame on the chap of six .
#Text=' I ascended the stairs with a sinking heart , for like all South Africans I have a horror of dirt .
#Text=The place was pretty filthy , but at each landing there were two doors with well-polished handles and brass plates .
#Text=On one I read the name of Andrew Amos .
#Text=A man in his shirt-sleeves opened to me , a little man , without a collar , and with an unbuttoned waistcoat .
#Text=That was all I saw of him in the dim light , but he held out a paw like a gorilla 's and drew me in .
#Text=The sitting-room , which looked over many chimneys to a pale yellow sky against which two factory stalks stood out sharply , gave me light enough to observe him fully .
#Text=He was about five feet four , broad-shouldered , and with a great towsy head of grizzled hair .

#Text=He wore spectacles , and his face was like some old-fashioned Scots minister 's , for he had heavy eyebrows and whiskers which joined each other under his jaw , while his chin and enormous upper lip were clean-shaven .
#Text=His eyes were steely grey and very solemn , but full of smouldering energy .
#Text=His voice was enormous and would have shaken the walls if he had not had the habit of speaking with half-closed lips .
#Text=He had not a sound tooth in his head .
#Text=A saucer full of tea and a plate which had once contained ham and eggs were on the table .
#Text=He nodded towards them and asked me if I had fed .
#Text=' Ye 'll no eat onything ?
#Text=Well , some would offer ye a dram , but this house is staunch teetotal .
#Text=I door ye 'll have to try the nearest public if ye 're thirsty . '
#Text=I disclaimed any bodily wants , and produced my pipe , at which he started to fill an old clay . '
#Text=Mr Brand 's your name ? ' he asked in his gusty voice .
#Text='
#Text=I was expectin ' ye , but Dod ! man ye 're late ! '
#Text=He extricated from his trousers pocket an ancient silver watch , and regarded it with disfavour . '
#Text=The dashed thing has stoppit .
#Text=What do ye make the time , Mr Brand ? '
#Text=He proceeded to prise open the lid of his watch with the knife he had used to cut his tobacco , and , as he examined the works , he turned the back of the case towards me .
#Text=On the inside I saw pasted Mary Lamington 's purple-and-white wafer .
#Text=I held my watch so that he could see the same token .
#Text=His keen eyes , raised for a second , noted it , and he shut his own with a snap and returned it to his pocket .
#Text=His manner lost its wariness and became almost genial .
#Text=' Ye 've come up to see Glasgow , Mr Brand ?
#Text=Well , it 's a steerin ' bit , and there 's honest folk bides in it , and some not so honest .
#Text=They tell me ye 're from South Africa .
#Text=That 's a long gait away , but I ken something aboot South Africa , for I had a cousin 's son oot there for his lungs .
#Text=He was in a shop in Main Street , Bloomfountain .
#Text=They called him Peter Dobson .
#Text=Ye would maybe mind of him . '
#Text=Then he discoursed of the Clyde .
#Text=He was an incomer , he told me , from the Borders , his native place being the town of Galashiels , or , as he called it , ' Gawly ' . ' I began as a powerloom tuner in Stavert 's mill .
#Text=Then my father dee 'd and I took up his trade of jiner .
#Text=But it 's no world nowadays for the sma ' independent business , so I cam to the Clyde and learned a shipwright 's job .
#Text=I may say I 've become a leader in the trade , for though I 'm no an official of the Union , and not likely to be , there 's no man 's word carries more weight than mine .
#Text=And the Goavernment kens that , for they 've sent me on commissions up and down the land to look at wuds and report on the nature of the timber .
#Text=Bribery , they think it is , but Andrew Amos is not to be bribit .
#Text=He 'll have his say about any Goavernment on earth , and tell them to their face what he thinks of them .
#Text=Ay , and he 'll fight the case of the workingman against his oppressor , should it be the Goavernment or the fatted calves they ca ' Labour Members .
#Text=Ye 'll have heard tell o ' the shop stewards , Mr Brand ? '
